I'll now turn the call over to Patty Yahn-Urlaub, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paula. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Constellation's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year End 2015 Conference Call. We have this morning is Rob Sands, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Bob Ryder, our Chief Financial Officer.Th
componenttext:
Thank you, Paula. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Constellation's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year End 2015 Conference Call. We have this morning is Rob Sands, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Bob Ryder, our Chief Financial Officer.
This call complements our news releases, which have also been furnished to the SEC. During this call, we may discuss financial information on a GAAP-comparable organic and constant-currency basis. However, discussions will generally focus on comparable financial results. Reconciliations between the most directly comparable GAAP measure and these and other non-GAAP financial measures are included in the news release or otherwise available on the company's website at www.cbrands.com. Please also be aware that we may make forward-looking statements during this call. Although statements represent our best estimates and expectations, actual results could differ materially from our estimates and expectations. For a detailed list of risk factors that may impact the company's estimates, please refer to the news releases and Constellation's SEC filings. And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Rob.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patty, and good morning, everyone. Before I begin the review of our accomplishments for the year and our plans for fiscal 2016, we'd like to focus your attention on the press release issued earlier today reporting that our Board of Directors has a
componenttext:
Thanks, Patty, and good morning, everyone. Before I begin the review of our accomplishments for the year and our plans for fiscal 2016, we'd like to focus your attention on the press release issued earlier today reporting that our Board of Directors has approved the initiation of a quarterly common stock cash dividend for the first time in the history of our company. This milestone is a particular significance because it reflects the confidence that we and our Board of Directors have in our ability to execute against growth opportunities, invest in our businesses and generate free cash flow that can be returned to you, our shareholders. It is the collective the strength of our businesses that has enabled this action and demonstrated by the impressive results achieved by the company in fiscal 2015. Since the acquisition of our beer business almost 2 years ago, we have had no shortage of milestones. Beer merchants is the #1 multi-category player in alcoholic beverage, and we are committing significant investment to our world-class brewery in Mexico. In our beer brands continue to achieve outstanding growth and garner accolades for their quality. For example, 6 of our wine and spirits brand and 3 of our beer brands won Impacts Hot Brands Awards for 2015 as announced in early March. Collectively, these accomplishments have driven the appreciation of our stock, which remains one of the best-performing stocks in the S&P 500 Consumer Staples Index. 
Now let's talk about some of our key achievements for fiscal 2015 and the great initiatives we have underway as we charge ahead to an exciting fiscal 2016. This past summer, we purchased Casa Noble Tequila, an award-winning, handcrafted super premium tequila, which has been a great addition to our portfolio. This fast-growing tequila brand naturally complements our Mexican beer brands and fits well into our existing wine and spirits distribution infrastructure. 
More recently, we hired our new, Chief Growth Officer, Bill Newlands, who is responsible for providing greater focus and coordination and the long-term growth opportunities across our beer and wine and spirits businesses. 
In addition, those accountable for accelerating innovation and new product development initiatives and leveraging strategic insights and customer analytics, while identifying synergies across total beverage alcohol within our national accounts organizations. Bill reports directly to me, and I am happy that he has joined our executive management team. 
One of our major accomplishments for the year was the implementation of a multi-faceted long-term glass strategy for our beer business under favorable terms with the key industry players which included the formation of a 50-50 joint venture with Owens-Illinois, the world's leading glass container producer to own, operate and expand the Nava glass plant. The acquisition by the joint venture of ABI's state-of-the-art glass plant located adjacent to our brewery in Mexico and the execution of a glass supply agreement with Mexican glass manufacturing -- manufacturer word, the benefits of which we will begin to fully realize once their Monterey glass plant has been completed. We believe this comprehensive sourcing strategy provides an optimal solution for this essential component of our beer production process, while securing future supply of materials in approved and finished products. 
Our commercial side of our business continue to achieve stellar growth in fiscal 2015 outperforming the U.S. beer industry, key competitors and all other imports for the fifth consecutive year with growth achieved by every brand in our Mexican beer portfolio. As a result, Constellation Brands beer business was the #1 contributor to growth in the U.S. beer category in fiscal 2015 while delivering market share growth across all channels in 48 out of 50 states. More importantly, our beer business growth has accelerated every year since 2010 and depletion trends accelerating to greater than 8% in fiscal 2015. 
I'd like to take a minute to share some of this past year's amazing accomplishments for our iconic beer brands and highlight the key initiatives we plan to execute during fiscal 2016 in order to maintain this excellent momentum for the business. 
Let's begin with the clear heavyweights in our portfolio, Corona, Extra and Modelo Especial. These brands are not only the biggest but have contributed the greatest incremental volume growth. Our flagship, Corona Extra brand, is the best selling imported beer in the United States. This brand sold more than 105 million cases in fiscal 2015 and posted depletion growth of more than 3% for the year. Corona Extra was the only top 5 beer brand in the U.S. to achieve growth last year with volume transfer this brand continuing to maintain their solid momentum. This fiscal 2016, we expect to capitalize on the growth of Corona Extra through increased national TV advertising, sports media, boxing sponsorships and by leveraging our acquisition of Casa Noble. 
According to guest metrics during calendar 2014, Corona Extra continued to be the #1 selling imported beer in the on-premise channel. To further support Corona Extra, we plan to increase our investment to expand activations in on-premise accounts throughout the year. Most importantly, fiscal 2016 will represent the year of the can for Corona Extra. We see great opportunity for growth with cans as this format currently represents 3% of total sales for Corona Extra. 
Last year, we represented another record-setting year for Modelo Especial with depletion growth of more than 16%. The Modelo Especial brand family contributed more dollar growth to the total beverage alcohol category than any other brand family in beer, wine or spirits in fiscal 2015. Modelo Especial has become the #2 imported beer in the U.S. with more than 15% share of the imported beer category, which is nearly double the share for this brand just 5 years ago. Our strategic initiatives in fiscal 2016 for Modelo Especial include: Increased media and general market advertising; continued execution with Modelo Especial Chelada; on-premise activation, retail sponsorships and promotion and Hispanic marketing and advertising and media investments. 
As you are aware, the best strength of our beer portfolio goes deeper than our 2 biggest brand.
Part of what makes our collection of brands so powerful is the long-term potential of our smaller brands. So let me provide some examples. 
Corona Light. Corona Light posted record sales in fiscal 2015 hitting the 14.5 million case mark and growing depletions almost 4% versus the prior year. We have had good success expanding the distribution of Corona Light Draft, and we plan to continue building on this success in fiscal 2016 by expanding our national draft footprint with recent launches in 8 additional markets. 
We are also relaunching Corona Light can, supported with redesigned secondary packaging, which will be featured in our new advertising campaign highlighting Corona Light as the light cerveza. Finally, we plan on continuing our partnership with Kenny Chelsea which has been a great asset for this brand. Victoria has become the third best selling beer in Mexico with a 15% market share of that market. In fiscal 2015, U.S. depletions for Victoria increased 60% [ph], driven primarily by the Mexican Hispanic consumer and expanded distribution for this brand into 19 new states. In fiscal 2016, we're excited to introduce Victoria cans into the U.S. market for the first time. Our support strategy for Victoria will focus on continuing to drive distribution and generate awareness for the new can format during key promotional period. 
Overall, I am excited about the organic growth prospects for our beer business this fiscal 2016. As you can see, we have tremendous opportunity to grow the business organically through enhanced distribution and execution opportunities across the portfolio. As a result for our beer business in fiscal 2016, we are targeting high single digit sales growth, which exceeds U.S. beer industry and import trends estimates that is expected to drive operating income growth in the 10% to 12% range. 
From a brewery and operational perspective in fiscal 2015, we achieved our key brewery performance goals related to word, quality and cost. Word of the brewery expansion are well underway with the project expansion on schedule from both the budget and timing of completion perspective. The packaging area and high-density warehouses are progressing on schedule as well as utilities and wastewater projects. Fabrication of beer tanks has been completed, and we recently added capacity to our can line in order to reduce our dependence on ABI for can. The new joint venture management team has been establishing the glass plant, and has begun work on the next glass furnace to be built on site at this newly acquired facility. The team has done an amazing job during brewery construction to minimize the impact on commercial business execution in the marketplace. 
As we begin fiscal 2016, we'll be intensely focused on the continued expansion of the brewery with the first incremental 10 million hectoliters of capacity expected to become fully operational that's more than a year from now in the summer of calendar 2016. 
Overall, I am extremely pleased with the outstanding commercial and operational performance of the beer business. This has been driven by a combination of robust consumer demand, strong sales execution, excellent from our wholesalers, creative new marketing and advertising programs as well as outstanding efforts of our commercial team and our brewery team in Mexico. 
And now, I'd like to focus on the operational results for our wine and spirits business. During fiscal 2015, we achieved EBIT growth of 6% for our wine and spirits business and increase operating profit margin by 130 basis points. Our spirits portfolio achieved better-than-expected results as well as our Canadian business, which exceeded its financial goals for the year, while growing share across all strategic product categories. Sales growth in the U.S. benefited from positive mix trends and some favorable pricing as we executed price increases in fiscal 2015 for select wine products in the value and luxury segments of the U.S. market while also growing distribution at key U.S. retailers. Wine and spirits EBIT growth was primarily driven by positive mix and COGS benefit, including reduced great cost as well as positive impact from ongoing blend optimization initiatives and productivity improvements. In addition, EBIT benefited from distributor performance payment as our exclusive distributor contracts included incentive structure that just based on achievement of specific executional performance metrics for the year. The terms of our overall U.S. depletion performance for fiscal 2015, our distributor sales to retail for consolations total U.S. wine and spirits business across all channels remain relatively flat. For this compares to EPS wine and spirits industry depletion growth of approximately 1% across all channels as reported by the Beverage Information Group for calendar 2014. As expected, our overall U.S. wine dollar market share eroded slightly in fiscal 2015 driven by the superpremium price segment, which remains highly competitive and currently generates a good deal of the U.S. wine category growth. However, we have gained share in the important premium and ultra-premium price segments of the market and are working diligently to ensure our portfolio remains relevant and top of line for our consumers in all key price segments. 
We continue to experience solid depletion growth for a number of our best growing wine brands, including Kim Crawford, Mark West, Ruffino, Black Box, Navalo and The Dreaming Tree. The strength of our portfolio begins with quality products and I'm very proud to say that we've achieved over 300 wine competition medals the last year and 52 of our wine design plus point ratings. This includes a 93.4 [indiscernible] for [indiscernible] Winery 2011 Cabernet Sauvignon reserve and the wine enthusiast and a 90-plus rating for our Ruffino reserve and word. And our list of achievements continues. 5 or brands made IRIs top 21 brands in 2014, including by Robert Mondavi, 15 of our brands were winners of the Beverage Information Group 2015 growth trend award, including 2 spirits and 13 wine brands. Many of our other wine brands continue to generate great media attention from a variety of news and lifestyle publications, including The Wall Street Journal Good Wine Magazine and Forbes.com to name a few. 
Earlier, I mentioned that 6 of our wines and spirits brands made Impact Hot Brands List. It's important to note that this list includes well-established brands such as Kim Crawford, which has won 8 years in a row, and Black Box celebrating its 10th consecutive win. This also includes The Dreaming Tree for the second year in a row, which is a testament to the level of success of our innovative efforts -- that our innovative efforts can achieve. 
We experienced excellent sales growth at 8% for our spirits portfolio in fiscal 2015  driven by Paul Masson Brandy and SVEDKA vodka. The recent data received from the Beverage Information Group for calendar 2014, SVEDKA is the only vodka amongst the top 5 largest volume vodka brands achieved growth for the year. In a category that is evolving as consumer preferences change, SVEDKA continues to win in the marketplace. SVEDKA innovative flavors like Strawberry Lemonade and Mango Pineapple are driving current success, and we look forward to seeing the results from our recent launch of our great flavor. 
In addition to success of Paul Masson, Peach Brandy has exceeded our own expectations, and we are currently expanding the product into additional formats and developing other new and exciting flavors for our brandy as we have done with our vodka and our whiskey brands. 
Overall, we gained IRI dollar share of imported vodka and Canadian whiskey categories for fiscal 2015. Our Casa Noble Tequila brand has been fully integrated into our portfolio, and we see significant opportunities to increase awareness and trial of this brand in the coming months. 
As we approach the Cinco de Mayo holiday, you will begin to see crosspromotional activities between Casa Noble and Corona Extra, which will help capture more merchandising and floorspace at retail and in the on-premise channels. From a strategic perspective, in 2016, our goal is to grow profit for the wine and spirits business, while also growing revenue, which is reflected in our fiscal 2016 wine and spirits guidance, to achieve low to single-digit sales growth and EBIT growth for the year. We also expect to maintain the margin improvement we achieved in 2015, and we are committed to executing the following strategies in an effort to make this goal a reality. We will continue to focus our marketing efforts on a subset of Focus Brands in order to drive key brands that have scale, higher margin and the greatest potential. These brands include Woodbridge, Kim Crawford and Black Box just to name a few. We remain committed to margin accretive innovation and new product development and have launched an enterprise-wide product development process review to improve our results in this area and increase the success rate of our new product pipeline. We have achieved dedicated business process to make sure our innovation is thoughtful and measured and positions us to ultimately win in this area. We believe we have a winner with our new Tom Gore wine brand in the coming year. We believe we plan to improve sales execution and increased points of distribution by delivering more effective feature and display activity at retail and added accountability and visibility for both Constellation and our distributors. 
Speaking of our distributors, our renegotiated exclusive as distributor arrangement are in place and will provide increase resources, improved performance metrics [indiscernible] wholesaler and reseller execution. For the second consecutive year, we plan to execute price increases to selected products in the value luxury segments of the U.S. wine market. 
And finally, we plan to optimize our COGS through continued global blend management initiatives, productivity improvements and lower-grade cost. Overall, we are committing people, technology and resources to our work with our wholesalers and retailers to execute growth for wine and spirits business. 
In closing, in fiscal 2015, we delivered industry-leading market results for our beer business while exceeding our goals across the board of volumes, depletions, sales and net income. Our wine and spirits business delivered improved margins and earnings growth with the Canadian business and our spirits portfolio achieving better-than-expected results. Overall, we remain committed to challenging ourselves in fiscal 2016 in order to optimize the business opportunities that lie ahead. Calendar 2015 marks the 70th anniversary of our business, which has become Constellation Brands. We are excited to build on this success to achieve in fiscal 2015 as we head into the new year with high expectations to create the next wave of growth for our company. 
With that, I would now like to turn the call over to Bob for our financial discussion of our fourth quarter and year-end results.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob. Good morning, everyone. Fiscal '15 was a very exciting and strong year, where we continued to strengthen our financial profile as we generated $6 billion of sales and 5% of organic sales growth. Expanded our operating margins in both segments
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob. Good morning, everyone. Fiscal '15 was a very exciting and strong year, where we continued to strengthen our financial profile as we generated $6 billion of sales and 5% of organic sales growth. Expanded our operating margins in both segments are consolidated comparable basis over the margin increase of more than 200 basis points, and established some all-time highs with consolidated EBIT reaching 1.6 [indiscernible] up nearly 30%, comparable basis diluted EPS, up more than 35%, $4.44, and operating cash flow up [ph] more than 30% crossing the $1 billion mark. We also reduced our overall average interest rate by securing attractive long-term financing, and we advanced our long-term strategy related to beer glass sourcing and made significant progress on our brewery expansion activities. We anticipate fiscal '16 to be another productive year as we expect to generate healthy net sales, EBITDA and EPS growth, while continuing to invest in our world class brewery as part of our efforts to become fully independent from a beer production standpoint. 
In addition, given the financial strength of each of our business segments and the resulting capital allocation flexibility, we're very pleased to be returning cash to shareholders through the initiation of a quarterly dividend. 
Given those highlights, let's look at fiscal '15 performance in more detail where my comments will generally focus on comparable basis financial results. As you can see from our earnings news release, consolidated net sales for the year were up 24%, which included $941 million of incremental net sales due to the timing of the beer business acquisition. Organic net sales on a constant-currency basis grew 5%. We continue to see robust marketplace momentum for our beer business with depletion growth of 8%. Beer shipment volume growth of 10% came in ahead of depletion growth as distributors increased their inventory position during the second half of the year in an effort to be more aligned with historical levels and to be better positioned to meet consumer demand heading into the key summer selling season. Pricing benefits helps beer net sales growth reach 12%. Wine and spirits net sales on a constant-currency basis increased 1%. This reflects positive mix combined with a distributor make-whole payment associated with a planned distributor destocking during the first quarter and distributor performance payments recognized during the fourth quarter, partially offset by lower volume for nonbranded net sales and higher promotional spend. For the year, consolidated gross profit increased $630 million. The increase primarily reflects $443 million of incremental benefit from the consolidating beer business for an additional 14 weeks in fiscal '15 as a result of the beer business acquisition as well as volume growth and favorable pricing for the base beer business and favorable mix and COGS for wine and spirits. Our consolidated gross margin increased 260 basis points to 43.8% for the year primarily due to the benefits of consolidating the higher-margin beer business and beer pricing. Favorable mix and COGS for the wine and spirits business as well as the distributor performance and destocking payments also contributed to the consolidated gross margin improvement. 
I would like to note that we have [indiscernible] gross profit and gross margin data in our segment disclosure in our press release and in our segment history file posted on our website. 
SG&A for the year increased $216 million. The incremental SG&A associated with consolidating the beer business was $134 million. The remainder of the increase was primarily due to higher marketing and SG&A for the base beer business. Due to the factors just mentioned, consolidated operating income increased $415 million and consolidated operating margin improved 230 basis points. Equity earnings decreased $56 million primarily due to the timing of the beer business acquisition. Interest expense for the year was $338 million, up 4% versus last year. The increase was primarily due to higher-average borrowings partially offset by lower average interest rates. 
That provides a good spot to discuss our debt position. At the end of February, our total debt was $7.3 billion. When factoring in cash on hand, our net debt totaled $7.2 billion, an increase of $281 million since the end of fiscal 2014. As a reminder, during Q3, we issued $800 million of senior notes consisting of $400 million of 3.875 notes due 2019 and $400 million of 4 3/4 notes due 2024. Part of the proceeds from the notes issuance was used to redeem $500 million of 8.375% senior notes. The remaining proceeds helped to fund the acquisition of the glass plant and related infrastructure. Our effective tax rate for the year came in at 29.5% and compares with 31.2% rate last year. The decrease was primarily driven by the benefit of foreign tax credits during the fourth quarter. 
Now let's briefly discuss Q4 results. Comparable basis diluted EPS for the quarter came in at $1.03, up 27%. The tax benefit I just mentioned was a big driver of our EPS growth as our Q4 tax rate came in at 23.2% versus the 34.8% rate in Q4 last year. Beer business results for the quarter finished strong. Depletions for the quarter were up 9 [indiscernible] volume and net sales were both up 11%. While we continue to see a pricing benefit during the quarter, it was essentially offset by certain adjustments to net sales related to the beer recall and other items recorded during the fourth quarter. Operating income was up 9%. Wine and spirits net sales on a constant-currency basis were up 2% for the quarter. This reflects the benefit of favorable mix and distributor performance payments, partially offset by lower volume. Wine and spirits operating income decreased 2% as higher marketing and SG&A costs unfavorably impacted quarterly results. 
Now let's discuss free cash flow, which we define as net cash provided by operating activities less capital spend. In fiscal '15, we generated $362 million of free cash flow compared to $603 million last year. Operating cash flow for fiscal '15 totaled $1.1 billion versus $826 million for the prior year. The increase was primarily due to the net benefits generated by the beer business. CapEx for fiscal '15 totaled $719 million compared to $224 million last year. CapEx for the beer segment totaled about $600 million and is primarily related to the brewery expansion. For fiscal '16, we expect free cash flow to be in the range of $100 million to $200 million. The free cash flow projection reflects operating cash flow of $1.15 billion to $1.35 billion and capital spending of $1.05 billion to $1.15 billion for fiscal '16. Our CapEx projection includes $950 million to $1.05 billion for the beer segment. Based on the midpoint of our guidance, we're targeting a 15% increase in operating cash for fiscal '16. This benefit is being more than offset by the increase in our CapEx spending related to the brewery and glass plants expansions. This activity is timing-related as these projects are progressing as planned from an overall cost and timing of completion perspective. As you'll see in our press release, we've provided an updated table summarizing the spending incurred and estimated future spending for these beer business projects. 
Now let's move to our full year fiscal '16 P&L outlook. Forecasting comparable basis diluted EPS to be in the range of $4.70 to $4.90 our share. Our comparable basis guidance excludes unusual items which are detailed in the release. The beer business is targeting mid-mid-single-digit volume growth, high single digit net sales growth and 10% to 12% operating income growth. Given the fiscal '15 beer shipments ran ahead of depletions, as distributors brought inventories at more historical levels, we expect our fiscal '16 depletion growth to be above shipment growth and to be in the high single digit range. A result that would continue to far outpace the import category in the total beer industry. Our guidance implies operating margin expansion for our beer business as we're projecting operating margins to be in the 33% range for fiscal '16. This is expected to be driven primarily by gross margin improvement as we plan to continue to make investments in marketing and our SG&A infrastructure at a higher rate than our level of net sales growth. 
For the wine and spirits business, we expect net sales and operating income growth to be in the low to mid-single-digit range. Volume growth is expected to be in the low single digit range, and we expect to generate positive mix, again take some pricing and generate additional COGS benefits. Interest expense is expected to be in the $325 million to $335 million range. Tax rate is expected to approximate 30.5%. Our guidance also factors in the initiation of a quarterly dividend. As Rob noted, this represents a significant milestone in our history, returning cash to shareholders demonstrates the confidence we have in the overall growth prospects and the strong free cash flow generation capabilities for both our beer and wine and spirits businesses. We're initially targeting a dividend payout ratio of 25% to 30% of our comparable basis net income. For fiscal 2016, we're anticipating approximately $240 million in dividend payments. We ended fiscal '15 with the net debt to comparable basis EBITDA leverage ratio of 4.1x. Even with our projected higher level of CapEx spend and the initiation of a dividend, our strong projected earnings and operating cash flow growth has us positioned to meet our targeted 3 to 4x leverage range during fiscal '16. Operating within our targeted leverage range, combined with our strong free cash flow generation, provide us significant financial flexibility. Going forward, as our beer CapEx spend normalizes, this provides us the ability to evaluate opportunities to increase our dividend and resume our share buyback program. 
In closing, I'd say that as we exit an eventful and successful 2015, the future looks equally bright. We're a leader in growing profitable consumer category and are critically important to our distributors and our retailers. At a consolidated level, a strong U.S. dollar and an improving U.S. economy are positive to Constellation, and we have minimal exposure to emerging markets. In wine and spirits, we continue to expect mid-single-digit sales growth for the industry. In fiscal '15, we increased our operating profit margin 130 basis points and finished the year with a margin of nearly 24%. We expect to maintain that margin in fiscal 2016. We have some work to do in order to reinvigorate our top line, but we have put in a lot of efforts against this area as reflected in our guidance. Longer term, we anticipate continued strong category growth, and we expect to at least maintain market share. In the beer segment, we continue to deliver industry-leading sales growth, and we continue to make progress towards our mid-30% operating profit margin goal. We're on schedule with our aggressive brewery and glass plant build outs, which requires us to reinvest most of our consolidated operating cash flow in 2015 [ph]. Our beer business generates very strong margins and very high operating returns on invested capital, so the payback on this investment should be quite fast. In beer, we feel our strong brand equity, marketplace and distributor network momentum, opportunities to increase portfolio distribution and grow sales in the can and draft format and favorable consumer demographics provide us with a very positive growth outlook. In addition to these positive business factors, we believe our strong cash-generation capabilities and our ability to quickly delever should provide us ample future opportunity to increase returns to shareholders through dividend growth and share buybacks. With that, we're happy to take your questions.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

componenttextpreview: A couple quick questions for me. Can you just clarify, you talked about other issues that affected the price number in beer. I just was hoping you could provide a little bit more clarity and exact what that was? And then the second question on the capital
componenttext: A couple quick questions for me. Can you just clarify, you talked about other issues that affected the price number in beer. I just was hoping you could provide a little bit more clarity and exact what that was? And then the second question on the capital allocation. When you talk about taking up the dividend, is this more about growing in line with earnings or openly [indiscernible] payout ratio kind of getting towards the higher end of your peer group, which is, I think, around 45% or so? And then the third question, sorry for the multiple questions, is in wine, what specific initiatives should we be looking at for to fully see the wine volume kind of what we've been seeing that past couple of quarters?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Nick. So on the first question -- it was a little bit garbled, but I think you're asking about Q4 pricing and Q4 beer margins. And essentially, what happened, it was really just a timing thing because of the big piece was because of the Corona recal
componenttext: Sure, Nick. So on the first question -- it was a little bit garbled, but I think you're asking about Q4 pricing and Q4 beer margins. And essentially, what happened, it was really just a timing thing because of the big piece was because of the Corona recall and we got fully reimbursed for that activity that just caused some anomalies as to how we account for that and the difference between what happens in sales and what happens in volume. And then there was another reclass that happened in the fourth quarter. What I would do is I would just look at the full year number to be more reflective of the real price volume [indiscernible]. For the second question, on the dividend. We're just starting out. I think we're very happy for the first time in the company's history to be instituting a dividend. And I think we wanted to start out probably on the lower level of where our peers are. And part of that is the fact that we're still right around the 4x EBITDA leverage ratio. We expect that to come down very fast. But we thought we'd start out a little slow. I'd say that we are focused on 25% to 30% payout ratio, and we feel the combination of pretty strong medium to longer-term EPS growth would allow us to grow the dividend in line with EPS, and in future years, we may actually assess whether where we want to be in that 25% to 30% payout lower at the lower end but certainly, we have room to go to the higher end of that range. The third question, which is more around wine volumes, I'll let Rob in.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Wine volumes, basically, Nik, we got a lot of programs that we put in place for our fiscal 2016 to drive, I'll say, better wine volume growth. And, in particular, we've got some increased marketing against the key brands. We have been increasing marketing
componenttext: Wine volumes, basically, Nik, we got a lot of programs that we put in place for our fiscal 2016 to drive, I'll say, better wine volume growth. And, in particular, we've got some increased marketing against the key brands. We have been increasing marketing, we've been doing a lot of research on exactly what kind of marketing will get us the best results. And we're implementing some new programs that we're very optimistic will, in fact, drive more sales growth in fiscal 2016 against key brands unless the whole portfolio versus 2015. We've got a lot of new programs around activation in the marketplace and sales execution to drive points of distribution as well as increased merchandising, display and other activity at retail around our brands. So a lot of the programs that we've put in place as we move into this year, and I would say we're pretty optimistic that we'll meet our top line goals.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bryan Spillane of Bank  of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bryan Spillane of Bank  of America.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just -- I guess 2 related question, just to clarify on the guidance for fiscal '16. One is, is just if you look at the margin on guidance in beer, Bob, you've got -- you're beginning to incur some of the operating expenses and expensing the expenses re
componenttext: So just -- I guess 2 related question, just to clarify on the guidance for fiscal '16. One is, is just if you look at the margin on guidance in beer, Bob, you've got -- you're beginning to incur some of the operating expenses and expensing the expenses related to the brewery expansion, so you've got can line in, you'll have more of the capacity, I guess, beginning to be tested in such. Could you just dimensionalize for us a little bit how much expense there is, how it's affecting the margins and maybe how long  have a dynamic where there's some expenses related to the start up that really don't have revenues attached to them?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So good question, Bryan. We experienced a little bit of this in the fourth quarter. As you bring these big lines, a bunch of things happened. First, they start to depreciate, these are brand-new lines, so the depreciation expense is not insigni
componenttext: Yes, sure. So good question, Bryan. We experienced a little bit of this in the fourth quarter. As you bring these big lines, a bunch of things happened. First, they start to depreciate, these are brand-new lines, so the depreciation expense is not insignificant. Secondly, as you bring them on and you're testing them, right off the bat, this lasts for quite a while. You're not getting very good yields, nor you're getting very good asset utilization. So that kind of increases your expenses, right. So it takes a while and these big lines are coming on to get them operating at full optimization. And so as we look at beer margins in '16, it was actually, there's some big movers, right? I mean we expect to save a reasonable amount of money because of glass, okay, because we'll be sourcing more glass from our joint venture location, which has no freight and has the lowest cost of produced glass of all our suppliers. That's a positive. Another big positive is foreign exchange. Offsetting that is an increase in depreciation, not insignificant, and some increased labor cost. You have these start-up expenses, and you're bringing on labor ahead of the time that you're actually getting a lot of usable products from those new production lines. So they're kind of the big offsetting things. That said, we have spent finished this year's operating profit margin pretty much exactly where we said we would, right around [indiscernible], and we're anticipating 100 basis point improvement even though we've got a lot of these new be big production lines coming on stream. So we're pretty happy with that guidance.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And if I could just sneak in the guidance range at 4 74 90, that was just kind of quickly plugging numbers in. Just kind of figure how you get to the higher end of the range because it seems like you can get to the middle of pretty easily, given sort of revenue in the margin guidance, is the high end of the range basically really going to be more predicated on how much -- how well sales do relative to your guidance, meaning be it the higher end or above? Or is the high end of that guidance range more tied to -- expand -- margin expansion?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably -- look, we're a consumer products company so the way we'd like to get it is through sales that are higher than we anticipate. And generally, that's what drives the on our consumer product P&L. So I'll probably say, the higher end of
componenttext: I think it's probably -- look, we're a consumer products company so the way we'd like to get it is through sales that are higher than we anticipate. And generally, that's what drives the on our consumer product P&L. So I'll probably say, the higher end of the guidance would be coming through the higher end of the guidance on our sales guidance.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

componenttext: The next question comes from Dara Mohsenian of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Bob standing in for Dara. I just have 2 questions. First on the long-term volume expectations for the beer business. You just like communicated a goal to distributors of roughly doubling the business by 2024 which implied a healthy 6% in your CAGR
componenttext: This is Bob standing in for Dara. I just have 2 questions. First on the long-term volume expectations for the beer business. You just like communicated a goal to distributors of roughly doubling the business by 2024 which implied a healthy 6% in your CAGR? I'm just curious, is this a real target investors should be focused on or more number distributors? And then second, if you could just provide updated color the U.S. beer price environment which has decelerated a bit, and then specific beer price strategy, is the plan really more geared towards relative pricing gaps or has strong volume growth really emboldened you guys to take more of an absolute approach?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob, on the first question, I'll answer a bit of it, and then I'll let Rob answer because he knows a lot  more about the industry than I do. When we provided our updated capital spending guidance earlier this year, we did provide some medium-term vol
componenttext: Yes, Bob, on the first question, I'll answer a bit of it, and then I'll let Rob answer because he knows a lot  more about the industry than I do. When we provided our updated capital spending guidance earlier this year, we did provide some medium-term volume guidance, which actually was driving the need to spend, to expand the brewery, right, from $20 million to $25 million. Actually, at that time, we said the medium-term volume guidance was mid-single digits, right? So I think your number was probably consistent, and that being said, next year's completion guidance is more like 8%, so it's higher than that. And so that was kind of the medium term [indiscernible] through fiscal '17 [ph] For a longer-term industry discussion, I'll hand over to Rob.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the answer to your question is definitely not high in the sky. I would say that doubling the business over the next 10 years is based on what we think is going to happen in the beer market and, in particular, how imports are going to continue
componenttext: Yes, I think the answer to your question is definitely not high in the sky. I would say that doubling the business over the next 10 years is based on what we think is going to happen in the beer market and, in particular, how imports are going to continue to grow and then how our portfolio is going to continue to grow based on what we see or know is going to happen with the Hispanic demographic group and the growth from ABIs in the group, we think that doubling the business over the next 10 years is certainly a doable number. I won't say that we got so detailed in our distributor meeting as exactly how that's going to occur, i.e., organically or otherwise, but of course, over the next 10 years we're going to have to have new products, new packaging, word, et cetera, to keep the growth of the portfolio as it is. Plus obviously, as Bob pointed out, we're starting out ahead of where we need to be CAGR-wise to achieve that. So I think we feel pretty optimistic that, that is a very achievable goal number.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then Bob, as far as the pricing comment, beer is a local business, so we look at pricing differently by geographic regions. We have different competitive dynamics in the different regions and different competitors take different pricing actions in the
componenttext: And then Bob, as far as the pricing comment, beer is a local business, so we look at pricing differently by geographic regions. We have different competitive dynamics in the different regions and different competitors take different pricing actions in the different regions. So we do pay attention to the momentum we have in those individual regions. But it is our key price gaps to our key competitors in those regions and kind of make decisions of those individual geographic regions and that kind of rolls up to the more macro number you will see reflected in IRI or Nielsen.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

componenttext: So I guess my first question is a little bit more clarification on what happened in the fourth quarter on the wine business because you had a pretty big gap in terms of shipments on the performance [indiscernible] and then you also called out the performance payments on distributors, which, I think, helps your revenue our margins. So can you just talk about some of the underlying trends? [indiscernible] number one, just the gap between shipments and depletions and then the distributor performance payments.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, in the fourth quarter is where we make certain adjustments basically in our shipments to distributors to make sure that shipments do, in fact, equal depletions. So there can be imbalances in the fourth quarter that are not necessarily reflective of t
componenttext: Yes, in the fourth quarter is where we make certain adjustments basically in our shipments to distributors to make sure that shipments do, in fact, equal depletions. So there can be imbalances in the fourth quarter that are not necessarily reflective of the whole year. So I think you really have to look at the whole year as opposed to quarter-to-quarter because there can be anomalies in the timing of shipments versus depletions. We also have some interruption in international business as a result of the Russia and this and that, but basically when you look at the whole year, this was pretty immaterial. What was your second question, Judy?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so also in connection with our distributor agreements and specifically in the fourth quarter of every year, this is where we sort of look at where our distributors have come in versus the goals of that were agreed upon and set. And then there are pay
componenttext: Yes, so also in connection with our distributor agreements and specifically in the fourth quarter of every year, this is where we sort of look at where our distributors have come in versus the goals of that were agreed upon and set. And then there are payments that are made in the fourth quarter that can actually go either way based on our distributors achievements of KPIs and former indicators. And those KPIs are things like sales mix, distribution, for example. So in the fourth quarter, they went our way last year, and thus, again, that causes some, I'll say, some sort of quarter-to-quarter anomalies. I think you're fundamentally -- you have to look at the whole year.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Bob, I just wanted to follow up on the capital allocation question. And this is really more 2017 type of question. But as you think about CapEx, obviously, setting down your free cash flow pretty meaningfully and the natural deleveraging ef
componenttext: Okay. And then Bob, I just wanted to follow up on the capital allocation question. And this is really more 2017 type of question. But as you think about CapEx, obviously, setting down your free cash flow pretty meaningfully and the natural deleveraging effect that has had some of the [indiscernible], how do you think about really the leveraging of the balance sheet to either buyback stock in more aggressive manner versus your free cash flow generation or you've been [indiscernible]?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Judy, that's a good problem to have, as you know, and we are looking forward to fiscal '17. And depending what's going on in the marketplace, my guess is we will probably increase the dividend that we how comparable net income increases. And as I said ear
componenttext: Judy, that's a good problem to have, as you know, and we are looking forward to fiscal '17. And depending what's going on in the marketplace, my guess is we will probably increase the dividend that we how comparable net income increases. And as I said earlier, we have the opportunity to go higher in that 25% to 30% payout ratio range. And I would probably anticipate that we reinvigorate our stock buyback program. We still have about $700 million authorized by the board as you know right before the beer deal in the previous like 12 to 18 months we've bought back about 20% of our outstanding shares just under $120 a share. That's worked out pretty well for us. I think it'll be a combination of those two. And I would presume that various tuck-in acquisitions in the beverage alcohol category might also come up. But as you said, as you look at the numbers, the free cash flow generation, when we get past this real high tranche of capital spending, it was really significant for our business. So we have a lot of flexibility on how to reinvest that cash. And I would presume the reasonable amount of it will go back to shareholders.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then if I could just squeeze in one last question. Bob, the glass sourcing in 2016 [ph],  can you give us a little bit of clarification in terms of what portion of your volume will come from various arrangements? Whether they be the vitro, the word arrangement you have with, just kind of rough breakdown of those relationships?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd rather not give real specific on that, but what I would reiterate is our lease expense in terms of glass, the facility that's right next to our brewery, right now it has 1 furnace that's operating. We've begun building furnace #2, and is planned
componenttext: Yes, I'd rather not give real specific on that, but what I would reiterate is our lease expense in terms of glass, the facility that's right next to our brewery, right now it has 1 furnace that's operating. We've begun building furnace #2, and is planned to go up to 4 furnaces, and they kind of come in over the next 4 years [ph]. So it's almost like 1 year comes in, right. So that volume will shift from other third-party suppliers to that local supplier. When it gets up to a total of 4 furnaces, it will be capable of providing roughly half of our needs in glass. So that's kind of how it's going to play out. The good news is that we're happy that -- we've landed that joint venture and we're thrilled with our JV partner. Owens-Illinois has already exhibited quite a bit of expertise in operating these glass facilities, and they tend to think very much like us, so there's no disagreements, unlike some other joint ventures that we might recall. And the other providers are also quite professional and quite good at what they do. And the good news is that in the total glass industry, glass is not a growing industry. We are growing our glass business. So we are a favored partner, so I think it's a very good partnership between us and all our glass suppliers.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Tim Ramey from Pivotal Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from Tim Ramey from Pivotal Research.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rob, as you think about your outlook on wine, how would that reconcile with your outlook on the overall wine industry? And where do you see the best growth, the pockets of growth, within the overall wine segment price points in 2016 [ph]?
componenttext: Rob, as you think about your outlook on wine, how would that reconcile with your outlook on the overall wine industry? And where do you see the best growth, the pockets of growth, within the overall wine segment price points in 2016 [ph]?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tim. We think that the wind industry, in general, in 2016 is going to grow sort of low single digits in volume, couple hundred basis points about that in dollars. So volume, 1% to 2%. Dollars, maybe 3% to 4%. Pretty consistently with what happened in
componenttext: Yes, Tim. We think that the wind industry, in general, in 2016 is going to grow sort of low single digits in volume, couple hundred basis points about that in dollars. So volume, 1% to 2%. Dollars, maybe 3% to 4%. Pretty consistently with what happened in 2015, depending on exactly what reports you're looking at, your sort of looking at 1% volume growth in 2015 and again, a couple of hundred basis points above that in dollar growth. In terms of where we're going to see the growth, it's pretty much the same story as historically has been the case, which there's, I think, pretty strong, continues to be very strong premiumization trend, all the growth and more in actuality is occurring and the premium plus category. And probably the thing that's changing is that it continues to move, I would say, upstream. It sort of started with sort of the bottom of the premium segment, $5 above. It moved up into what we call this super premium segment, which is sort that $8 to $10, meaning the growth, that's been very strong. Now we're seeing the very strong growth in segments above that. So ultra-premium and luxury really, I would say, a lot -- you're going to see very strong growth in sort of that almost $13 to $20 range. You're probably going to see double-digit growth. In terms of parietals, I think that you'll see decent lower levels of growth in the most word Cabernet Sauvignon, I think pinot noir is going to continue to be a very stable and hot category in wine. I think in white wine, you're going to continue to see very strong growth in pinot grigio and of course, New Zealand Sauvignon Blancs, I think they're going to continue to be a very hot category. And then I think another phenomena -- or I won't quite call it a phenomena, but a bit of a change in trend is sparkling wines. I think that sparkling wines had become very hot once again or I should say, once again, but again, they haven't been that hot over the last, I don't know, 5, 6, 7, 10 years. And you're seeing some of the more affordable categories in sparkling wines like Prosecco, and some of the domestic California sparklers become hot, and I'd say, more everyday. I mean, people are turning to sparkling wine as an everyday product. So what you don't see as particularly hot is champagne, i.e., French champagne. But I think it's priced itself out of the market largely. And the consumer has turned to I'd say, more reasonably priced and easier drink alternative than champagne. So sweet reds will continue to be, I think, a trend in the marketplace. So sort of big, robust slightly, when we talk about sweet reds, slightly sweeter generic red wines. That's been a pretty significant trend, and we don't see that diminishing in the near future. At the low end, where has been kind of up and down a little bit. So probably going to continue favorably, but not as robust as it was a couple of years ago. So those are the trends, Tim.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good stuff. Bob, with regard to the construction costs and timing, I understand a lot of things like Steeler dollar base. But are there peso-based cost associated with Nava facility and is that having a benefit to the overall estimate of cost there?
componenttext: Good stuff. Bob, with regard to the construction costs and timing, I understand a lot of things like Steeler dollar base. But are there peso-based cost associated with Nava facility and is that having a benefit to the overall estimate of cost there?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most of it, as you said, Tim, most of the machinery and equipment are dollar based. Actually most of the commodities in production are dollar based. The big local cost, of course, is Mexican labor. So Mexican labor being used on the construction will on t
componenttext: Most of it, as you said, Tim, most of the machinery and equipment are dollar based. Actually most of the commodities in production are dollar based. The big local cost, of course, is Mexican labor. So Mexican labor being used on the construction will on the balance sheet, right, and that will come down in [indiscernible] but it's not a huge percent of the cost. And the same thing on operations. Mexican labor in the plants in the glass plant, right, because we employ a lot of people down there [indiscernible] geometrically. And as long as the dollar stays strong and the peso, that'll be a bit of the benefit as well. But the good news is because our end selling price in beer is based in U.S. dollars, we're not very foreign exchange exposed., which is a great place to be, right, because you remember Australian wine for those years when the Aussie dollar got so strong, it's very hard to maintain a good gross profit margin. So we're balanced in the currency of our input cost and the currency of our selling price, which is just a really good long place  business model, a good place to be.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

componenttext: Word in for Bill. I have 2 questions. First, [indiscernible] great cost inflation [indiscernible] what you expect [indiscernible] to begin your [indiscernible]. Just my second question looking at [indiscernible], you mentioned [indiscernible] can you provide delivered more [indiscernible] specific brand [indiscernible]?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I can take the first one on grapes. So we're actually doing very well on our grape cost. We had a very good year in fiscal '15, and I take my hat off to our operations guys in the wine business, the guys, the winemakers blending the wine and the guy
componenttext: Sure. I can take the first one on grapes. So we're actually doing very well on our grape cost. We had a very good year in fiscal '15, and I take my hat off to our operations guys in the wine business, the guys, the winemakers blending the wine and the guys in charge of sourcing the grapes and farming their grapes because we did a very good job buying wine and the landed cost per ton is kind of flat to even down a little bit, and we've done a very good job on refining our wine blends to make the cost to the consumer a little bit less. So we're looking good on the wine side, which is why one of the big reasons why we said we expect to maintain the improved gross profit margin that we experienced in the wine segment in 2015. The question around Victoria Pacifico, I'll let Rob answer.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Victoria is one of the -- typical -- is one of the smaller brands in our portfolio. I actually think that it's a real sleeper. It's a brand that has a lot of opportunity for the future, much like we saw Modelo Especial explode that brand. Pacifico
componenttext:
Yes. So Victoria is one of the -- typical -- is one of the smaller brands in our portfolio. I actually think that it's a real sleeper. It's a brand that has a lot of opportunity for the future, much like we saw Modelo Especial explode that brand. Pacifico, primarily West Coast, primarily Southern California, is it's really big base of business. We're focusing our marketing around things like the World Surfing Championships. We've got advertising campaigns in place around basically discovered by surfers in Mexico, Baja. So -- and we've got a draft program for Pacifico, which has been, I would say, very well received. So a smaller brand in the portfolio, but something with a lot of potential. Victoria, again, a small brand, but the interesting thing about Victoria is it's the third largest brand in Mexico with a 50% [ph] market share, and it's very well-known by the Hispanics -- Mexican Hispanic consumer, which really gives us a huge leg up versus any other new product that could be introduced in Mexico -- from Mexico to the U.S. A lot of these products that -- or 1 or 2  that have been recently introduced are fundamentally made up products that Hispanic consumers never heard of. I mean, that's a tough sell in that demographic. With Victoria, we've also introduced cans.
We're expanding the distribution nationally, and we're seeing some pretty strong growth, as I've commented on initially of 60% growth on that brand in last year, and we see that momentum remaining strong into this year. I mentioned just, in general, cans. Cans is a huge opportunity for us. Across all of our brands, Corona, Modelo Especial, brands, we're really stepping up can introduction, and it's an interesting trend in the beer business, in general, is that cans have gone from being perceived as sub-premium to being perceived as very premium form of packaging. And that's probably driven by the fact that draft portion of the business, which is the other very fast-growing portion of the business other than our portfolio, okay, has really adopted at a very high end can as their primary packaging, and the consumers really accepted that. So that sure kind of opened the window that can is a great form of package for our business. And then you look at our business for can, we have not been cans at all, cans represent approximately 3% of our total business. But if you look at the industry as a whole, is like half of the beer business is in cans. So the growth potential for cans is just absolutely phenomenal in our business, and in our own particular case, as we've introduced cans, we've really seen it expand consumption as opposed to just simply cannibalize other forms of packaging because we haven't had packaging that, I'll say, is appropriate for the kind of venues where cans are particularly strong in the past. So this has been a big, big advantage for us.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from Caroline Levy of CLSA.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015

componenttext: I just like to dig into the D&A situation. And in some way, frame what was the actual numbers that you're expecting for fiscal '16? Or maybe say that it's certainly not going to be a big from your glass savings? But what I'm worried about is that, at some point, we say that the D&A alone is kind of offsetting all the benefits of all-in growth and so on? If you could help us get comfortable with that, that'll be really helpful.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so good question, Caroline. Look, our is going up right because we're spending all this capital obviously. So in fiscal '16, our is probably going to go up 20% to 25% over fiscal '15, and that's because we're bringing on these new production line, an
componenttext: Yes, so good question, Caroline. Look, our is going up right because we're spending all this capital obviously. So in fiscal '16, our is probably going to go up 20% to 25% over fiscal '15, and that's because we're bringing on these new production line, and actually towards the end of the year, we actually bring on some hectoliters of beer. So as that stuff goes into service, you start depreciating it. That does create P&L headwinds, right, as you go forward. But even with all that, as we discussed, we're estimating that our operating profit margin, the beer segment, is up about 100 bps next year, and we're still reiterating the fact that we expect to get to the mid-30% [ph] range by the time that 20 million hectoliters [indiscernible] out.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to clarify, are you also -- you also very [indiscernible] to get out what the inefficiencies of testing the lines and so on cost to you? Because again, this is very new for you guys sometimes margin are going to be hit by the inefficiencies
componenttext: Okay. And just to clarify, are you also -- you also very [indiscernible] to get out what the inefficiencies of testing the lines and so on cost to you? Because again, this is very new for you guys sometimes margin are going to be hit by the inefficiencies of opening a new brewery and you obviously wouldn't be at full capacity for a little bit.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean the good news, and again we're quite anomalous in this regard because it's not like we're building the brewery capacity utilization from organic growth, right? We're moving the production from InBev to us, so although we won't be bringing the
componenttext: Yes, I mean the good news, and again we're quite anomalous in this regard because it's not like we're building the brewery capacity utilization from organic growth, right? We're moving the production from InBev to us, so although we won't be bringing the line up to the maximum capacity utilization that it is now, it will still be better than what you might see in other industries as of they build, say, a greenfield facility, and it takes them, say, 10 years to get up to full capacity utilization. We won't be as slow as that. And then as far as when these production lines come up, these are big complicated things. And as you know, our breweries highly automated, so there's a lot of software IT stuff going on. And every line, you can't necessarily anticipate the gremlins that will come up. So we're doing everything we can to offset that, but stuff happens. But we don't think that, that will be in any way material, and it will be relatively short-lived. And we're not expecting that to happen, but you can't. That's all reflected in the guidance that we provided this fiscal year.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the big reason for that is the -- is kind of ramped up marketing spend, will be the big reason for that. In the beer industry -- in our beer business, we've increased our marketing spend in fiscal '14, it was about 8% of sales, and we went up to a
componenttext: Yes, so the big reason for that is the -- is kind of ramped up marketing spend, will be the big reason for that. In the beer industry -- in our beer business, we've increased our marketing spend in fiscal '14, it was about 8% of sales, and we went up to about 8.5% of sales in fiscal '15, right, as we got into general market advertising for Modelo Especial, got a little more aggressive against Corona in the phase of the glass recall because we wanted to completely negate any potential brand equity loss that we have there. I think we're successful on that. And as Rob said earlier, we're ramping up some marketing around Pacifico. So -- and we think that, that's been a very effective spend, and the beer marketing guys actually do a very good job of tracking volume with and the effectiveness of the various marketing expenditures. So that's the big reason why the operating profit line will come down a little bit. And then also the question Nik asked earlier, this anomaly in the fourth quarter because of the Corona glass recall and some other reclass and also hurt the fourth quarter, as long as our marketing spend, as Rob said earlier, we're are also increasing our marketing spend in wine, right, because we're a branded consumer product business, and we think that's important to keep the consumer brand equity going across our categories.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple questions. First, also the margins trends here in beer, Bob. Oil prices eventually should be a benefit to your shipping cost for Mexico here to the U.S. Can you just give us a flavor for how beneficial that's been and how beneficial that might be
componenttext: A couple questions. First, also the margins trends here in beer, Bob. Oil prices eventually should be a benefit to your shipping cost for Mexico here to the U.S. Can you just give us a flavor for how beneficial that's been and how beneficial that might be?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so good question because it's kind of a macro trend that you guys are probably seeing a lot of companies. So net net, even at this day, this is net good news for us because obviously, we will benefit from the reduced oil prices on our the unhedged po
componenttext: Yes, so good question because it's kind of a macro trend that you guys are probably seeing a lot of companies. So net net, even at this day, this is net good news for us because obviously, we will benefit from the reduced oil prices on our the unhedged portion of our oil exposure, and most of our oil exposure is around freight, and there's more in beer than wine because they just ship more cases. So I'd say, oil prices is a net positive for us, but when you guys get into the numbers, you'll see that we still had around a $30 million loss on I'll say, unrealized commodity hedges. Most of those was around diesel hedges. Those losses will flow through the P&L over the next 2 years. A reasonable amount will flow through the P&L in fiscal '16, that will have been included in our guidance. But net net, the reduction to oil prices, I'll say, from a fiscal '16 is a positive, and of course, if they stay low, it will be even more of a positive side as out-of-the-money hedges get behind us.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And is it fair to think at the moment when you're bringing beer into the U.S., you're bringing some sort of, so to speak, of your own beer from Nava and then some that's being purchased from ABI still. So the actual shipping cost for those 2 class
componenttext: Got it. And is it fair to think at the moment when you're bringing beer into the U.S., you're bringing some sort of, so to speak, of your own beer from Nava and then some that's being purchased from ABI still. So the actual shipping cost for those 2 classes of beer, is there any difference -- I mean, we know that, obviously, as it gets into Nava, it gets closer to the U.S, but the actual cup of per mile charge of getting it to a given location in the U.S. from a brewery that's owned by ABI versus a brewery that's owned by you, is that -- are they one and the same or is there some difference in that regard too?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's actually reasonable amount of difference, let's see. Quantitative difference, there's a lot more miles that we travel in the U.S. than we do in Mexico, of course, right? I'll also say that very different freight negotiations, south of the border a
componenttext: There's actually reasonable amount of difference, let's see. Quantitative difference, there's a lot more miles that we travel in the U.S. than we do in Mexico, of course, right? I'll also say that very different freight negotiations, south of the border and north of the border. So south of the border, there's not as much competition around freight, and south of the border is almost exclusively rail freight that we do. And actually even north of the broader, most of our cost is rail freight as well. But I'd say that they are very different competitive environments in Mexico versus the U.S.

componenttext: Yes, I mean our desired range would be in between 3 and 4. We're trying to balance a lot of constituents. Obviously, the rating agencies would like to us to be very well in that range, and probably shareholders would like us to be high in that range because they've that what we do is borrow money and give cash back to shareholders. So we're taking both into account. So I think probably ideal is in between 3 and 4.

componenttext: Got it. Okay. Last one on that. If we just think about M&A, you've commented on this a few times over the last few quarters, and Rob, you made a comment that you're open to M&A in the beer business and certainly, there could be some plug ins. But when we think about M&A in terms of share scale, whether it's beer or wine and spirits, how are you thinking about this scale of any acquisition you might do in terms of like the upper limit on such actions?

componenttextpreview: Yes, we think about scale, we're really talking, I think, primarily about tuck-in brand type of acquisitions in the couple hundred million probably range or less. There just isn't -- there's anything really big in any of the 3 categories, I'd say ostensib
componenttext: Yes, we think about scale, we're really talking, I think, primarily about tuck-in brand type of acquisitions in the couple hundred million probably range or less. There just isn't -- there's anything really big in any of the 3 categories, I'd say ostensibly makes a lot of sense to us. So it's really just, I would say, opportunistic tuck-in brand type opportunities across the 3 categories.

componenttext: In terms of the draft business, we haven't talked about that too much today. Is the percent of your business in draft is about 2% to 3%, is that right? How much was it up last year? And can you talk a little bit about what percentage of the potential account you have draft available now for Corona Extra and Corona Light, please?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We continue to -- I'll start off, and then Rob can follow up. We continue to be very bullish on draft. We feel that we can sell quite well into retailers because our brands can distinguish themselves from amongst the thousands of IPAs out here that a
componenttext: Yes. We continue to -- I'll start off, and then Rob can follow up. We continue to be very bullish on draft. We feel that we can sell quite well into retailers because our brands can distinguish themselves from amongst the thousands of IPAs out here that are on draft handles that lead turn as fast as us. We think right now Corona Light is our biggest opportunity for draft. And Corona Light pretty much, from a small base but double this draft volume in fiscal '15. As far as Corona Extra draft, that's still in a very small test right now. So the big portion is on Corona Light. And I think Pacifico is probably our largest draft brand. But our brands really positioned themselves very well in draft accounts.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think the only thing that I would add as much as I can that represents the relatively small percentage of our business and a relatively large percentage of the overall beer business, so it remains a big opportunity for us. We're being prude
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think the only thing that I would add as much as I can that represents the relatively small percentage of our business and a relatively large percentage of the overall beer business, so it remains a big opportunity for us. We're being prudent in how we introduce draft for our biggest brand, Corona Extra to see how it impacts the brand where it's traditionally been only a glass on-premise. So we're interested to see exactly what happens in those accounts where we put draft in. I think that sort of the results of our testing, thus far, has been -- the way we put draft in even in high market share on-premise establishments that tends to be market expanding as opposed to purely cannibalistic. So we think that, that's a very positive trend. Of course, everything that we do, we do it keeping in mind that we're not going to cannibalize lower -- higher margin versus lower-margin business can. Draft is essentially the same kind of margin structure as our other package format, in general, so we're not overly concerned with it. But on the other hand, we certainly would -- we like the fact that it appears to be significantly market expanding when we put it. We actually tend to see increased sales of glass in a surrounding area when we put draft, Corona Extra draft into an establishment. And that's sort of been, I think, the traditional thinking on draft, is that it not only has just a benefit from a pure word point of view, the format consumer product, but it also has a marketing or advertising component that helps to sell your other packages off premise, and we are definitely seeing that.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's terrific. And then just on cans. Can you give us a sense to where you are in terms of rolling out your can capacity? How much is in-house right now? And how much do you -- what percentage do you rely on ABI? And at what point will you be 100% in-ho
componenttext: That's terrific. And then just on cans. Can you give us a sense to where you are in terms of rolling out your can capacity? How much is in-house right now? And how much do you -- what percentage do you rely on ABI? And at what point will you be 100% in-house on cans?

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're pretty much self-sufficient on cans right now, having put in our can capacity already, and we can produce pretty much as much in cans as we could possibly need. As I've said, we're just rolling out a new  can for Corona Extra. Corona Extra h
componenttext: Yes. So we're pretty much self-sufficient on cans right now, having put in our can capacity already, and we can produce pretty much as much in cans as we could possibly need. As I've said, we're just rolling out a new  can for Corona Extra. Corona Extra has been about, I think, 3% from cans. So very huge opportunity. Our business overall, meaning everything combined, is about 20% from cans in the market so I think closer to about 50% cans. So huge opportunity there, and no capacity constraints whatsoever, and we can supply 100% of our cans at this stage, so it's the year of the can.

headline: Constellation Brands Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 09, 2015
